subject: Public Speaking
title: Abraham Lincoln's Stage Fright
description: A micro-lesson that makes Abraham Lincoln's Stage Fright usable.

hook.text: Abraham Lincoln â€” one of history's greatest speakers â€” had a high, thin voice and trembled at the start of speeches.

buildup.text: Witnesses described him as visibly nervous for the first few minutes, with shaking hands and an unsteady voice.

discovery.text: But as he warmed up, his passion took over. The nervousness channeled into intensity that audiences found magnetic.

twist.text: Lincoln's anxiety never went away. He just learned to start speaking through it rather than waiting for it to pass.

climax.text: His example shows that courage isn't the absence of fear. It's speaking while afraid, trusting the message to carry you.

punchline.text: Even Lincoln's hands shook. He spoke anyway.

quiz.question: How did Lincoln handle his stage fright?
options: He spoke through the nervousness until passion took over
